An **iron chain** is a type of [item](/wiki/Item "Item") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is naturally made of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron").

Iron chains are classified under the "[chain](/wiki/Chain "Chain")" object type, rather than [tools](/wiki/Tool "Tool") or [weapons](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
  - [2.1 Improvised uses](#Improvised_uses)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [4.2 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [4.3 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [4.4 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

[Punishment](/wiki/Punishment "Punishment") causes a [heavy iron ball](/wiki/Heavy_iron_ball "Heavy iron ball") to be attached to you by an iron chain.

Destroying a [drawbridge](/wiki/Drawbridge "Drawbridge") will send several iron chains flying or generate them in piles near the bridge's former square, depending on if it was open or closed at the time.

[Iron golems](/wiki/Iron_golem "Iron golem") leave 2-8 iron chains behind as a special [death drop](/wiki/Death_drop "Death drop") in lieu of a [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse"), which are the primary source of most iron chains in an average game.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Strategy

The iron chain's primary function is keeping an heavy iron ball attached to you - you can end punishment by directly removing the chain, such as using the [#monster](/wiki/Monster_\(command\) "Monster (command)") [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command") while [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a nymph, or eating the chain while in the form of a [metallivore](/wiki/Metallivore "Metallivore"). Other methods of ending punishment will also cause the chain to disappear.

Otherwise, the iron chain is essentially [junk](/wiki/Junk "Junk"): whereas items such as the [ring of aggravate monster](/wiki/Ring_of_aggravate_monster "Ring of aggravate monster") can have some important use cases, the iron chain is generally considered the most useless item in *NetHack* - they perform no function as individual objects, have no value when sold to shopkeepers, and aren't of any real use as a weapon despite their [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight"). Even the [cheap plastic imitation of the Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Cheap_plastic_imitation_of_the_Amulet_of_Yendor "Cheap plastic imitation of the Amulet of Yendor") can at least be [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into another useful amulet - an iron chain will always polymorph into another iron chain.

### Improvised uses

Here are several, somewhat trivial uses for these objects:

- Throw or kick them as missiles.
- If the player is a [Healer](/wiki/Healer "Healer"), [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest"), [Ranger](/wiki/Ranger "Ranger"), [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist "Tourist"), or [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") going for [weaponless](/wiki/Weaponless "Weaponless") conduct, a chain will do more damage than Basic or Skilled [bare hands](/wiki/Bare_hands "Bare hands") (d4+1 vs d2+1 damage). Well-enchanted [kicking boots](/wiki/Kicking_boots "Kicking boots") will still be superior, however.
- Food for pet metallivores, or for you while [polyselfed](/wiki/Polyself "Polyself") into a metallivore.
- Leave them in the path of hostile metallivores as a distraction.
- Polypile enough of them to make another iron golem, and either turn it into your pet or polymorph it into a monster worthy of sacrificing (though one is likely better off using the golem they killed in the first place if they can do this). If particularly bored, taming it and watching it get killed by a [rust monster](/wiki/Rust_monster "Rust monster") will produce an [amusing message](/wiki/YAFM "YAFM").
- Carry them in your main inventory to lower the chance that something "good" will be cursed or stolen. (Consider using lighter objects such as worthless [gems](/wiki/Gem "Gem") instead.)
- Leave a [bones file](/wiki/Bones_file "Bones file") that will annoy others (using ASCII): "Darn, that's not an altar." (This *might* be considered very mild [griefing](/wiki/Griefing "Griefing").)

## History

The iron chain first appears in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0").

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and earlier versions, including some variants based on those versions, iron chains could be used to mark the [vibrating square](/wiki/Vibrating_square "Vibrating square"). Prior to [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1"), they could also be used as a [Vladsbane](/wiki/Vladsbane "Vladsbane").

## Variants

Some variants may elect to make iron chains somewhat useful in certain cases.

The [Convict](/wiki/Convict "Convict") is a role that appears in many variants, and starts the game with a heavy iron ball attached to them by chain - various iron chains are also among the prison debris encountered in the upper levels of the [Convict quest](/wiki/Convict_quest "Convict quest").

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), [applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a bag of tricks that is [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") or has been [charged](/wiki/Charged "Charged") has a 1⁄20 chance of spitting out an iron chain, which replaces the random item a non-cursed or non-recharged bag would generate.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), monsters that hate iron will avoid squares with iron chains on them.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), iron chains have uses in creating items at a [furnace](/wiki/Furnace "Furnace"):

- You can create a heavy iron ball by combining an iron chain and a [boulder](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder").
- You can create a [spiked chain](/wiki/Spiked_chain "Spiked chain") by combining an iron chain with either a dagger or a knife.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), iron chains can be found at junk [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop"), and have several uses in [crafting](/wiki/Crafting "Crafting") recipes at [forges](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)"). An iron chain can be used to make several other items:

- An iron chain can be combined with 2 [shuriken](/wiki/Shuriken "Shuriken") to create a spiked chain.
- An iron chain can be combined with a [flintlock](/wiki/Flintlock "Flintlock") to create a [pistol](/wiki/Pistol "Pistol").
- An iron chain can be combined with a pistol to create a [submachine gun](/wiki/Submachine_gun "Submachine gun").
- An iron chain can be combined with a submachine gun to create a [heavy machine gun](/wiki/Heavy_machine_gun "Heavy machine gun").
- An iron chain can be combined with a [rifle](/wiki/Rifle "Rifle") to create a [sniper rifle](/wiki/Sniper_rifle "Sniper rifle").
- An iron chain can be combined with 2 [darts](/wiki/Dart "Dart"), 2 [daggers](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger") or 2 [knives](/wiki/Knives "Knives") to create a stack of [bullets](/wiki/Bullet "Bullet").
- An iron chain can be combined with 2 bullets to create a [shotgun shell](/wiki/Shotgun_shell "Shotgun shell").

## Encyclopedia entry

"You are fettered, " said Scrooge, trembling. "Tell me why?"  
"I wear the chain I forged in life," replied the Ghost. "I made it link by link, and yard by yard; I girded it on of my own free will, and of my own free will I wore it. Is its pattern strange to you?"  
Scrooge trembled more and more.  
"Or would you know," pursued the Ghost, "the weight and length of the strong coil you bear yourself? It was full as heavy and as long as this, seven Christmas Eves ago. You have laboured on it, since. It is a ponderous chain!"

\[ A Christmas Carol, by Charles Dickens ]
